cards.back: Converting continuous-domain problems (time, space, frequency) into discrete-point problems for digital processing. Core idea: sample at specific points, losing information between samples.
x[n] = x(nTs) for n = 0, 1, 2, ... where Ts is the sampling period. Converts continuous x(t) to discrete x[n].

cards.front: What is the forward finite difference formula?
cards.back: df/dx ≈ (f(x+h) − f(x))/h. Error: O(h) — first-order accurate. Halving h halves the error.

cards.front: What is the central second difference formula?
cards.back: d²f/dx² ≈ (f(x+h) − 2f(x) + f(x−h))/h². Error: O(h²) — second-order accurate. Used for Laplace's equation.

cards.front: Why is central difference more accurate than forward difference?
cards.back: Central differences use symmetric information (both sides of x), which cancels the leading O(h) error term by symmetry. Result: O(h²) accuracy vs O(h).
Both time and frequency. x(t) → x[n] (time sampling) and X(f) → X[k] (frequency sampling). N time samples ↔ N frequency bins.

cards.front: What is the frequency resolution of an N-point DFT?
cards.back: Δf = fs/N. More samples (larger N) = finer frequency resolution. Example: fs = 1000 Hz, N = 1000 → Δf = 1 Hz.

Where do discretization and approximation overlap?
cards.back: When replacing derivatives with finite differences: the grid is discretization (continuous → discrete domain), but the finite difference formula is also an approximation (exact derivative → approximate formula).

cards.front: What error types does discretization introduce?
cards.back: Aliasing (sampling below Nyquist) and discretization error (replacing continuous operations with discrete approximations, e.g., finite differences). Distinct from statistical or linearization error.
